description: Write n in base 3, then (working from left to right) if the k-th digit of n is equal to the corresponding digit to the left of the k-th digit of a(n) then 1 is the k-th digit of a(n), otherwise the k-th digit of a(n) is 0, then read result as a base 2 number.
example: a(76) = 10 since 76 written in base 3 is 2211 and looking for changing digits produces 1010 which read as if in binary is 10.
crossrefs: k appears A001316(k) times in the sequence.
author: _Henry Bottomley_, Apr 04 2001
